title: Optimising Traffic Flow with Calculus
summary: How traffic engineers use differential calculus to find optimal signal timings that minimise average waiting times at Indian intersections.
content:
Case Study: Traffic Flow Optimisation

Indian cities like Mumbai, Delhi, and Bengaluru have some of the world's most congested traffic. Traffic engineers model vehicle flow using differential equations and optimisation — a direct application of calculus. The goal: find signal cycle times that minimise average delay per vehicle.

Key Mathematical Concepts

  • Objective Function: Total average delay D(t) as a function of green-phase duration t.
  • Differentiation: Find dD/dt = 0 to locate the minimum delay point.
  • Second Derivative Test: Confirm d²D/dt² > 0 to verify it is a minimum, not a maximum.
  • Constraints: The optimisation is subject to constraints (minimum safe crossing time, maximum cycle length).

Real-World Impact

Adaptive signal control systems, now deployed in several Indian cities, continuously recompute optimal timings using real-time traffic data. The mathematics of constrained optimisation saves millions of person-hours of waiting time daily.
